subject: Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... to my argument was a contrapositive: If we wrote QS phonetically... I m using a reductio ad absurdum argument.  Your analysis simply shows that we do not
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Gregory Weidman <delrayva@...>
wrote:
>
>
> Mr. Grahn,
>
> In your message below, I think you missed my point. The predicate
to my argument was a contrapositive: "If we wrote QS phonetically..."
I'm using a reductio ad absurdum argument. Your analysis simply
shows that we do not write QS phonetically, and that this is a good
thing. If we assign IPA values to QS glyphs, then we are obliged to
write phonetically, and my predicate would no longer be a
contrapositive, and the result would be an "absurdum."
>
> So, your analysis, while interesting, ends up making my point rather
than refuting it.
>
> Greg Weidman
>

Mr Weidman,

Yes non phonetic words account for all the minor words such as "the"
"a" "we" "which" "he" etc and they are usually represented by a single
letter and so not prejudiced toward a particular accent. Yet these
single letter words account for a large percent of the text.
But in a critical way I contend both samples were written
phonetically *within their accent* (all words beyond a fixed set of
the 60 most common are phonetic). But each accent builds a *slightly*
different IPA map to each letter and no two accents use different
letters for the same sound. The result is both phonetic and yet
demonstrably virtually the same spelling. When read in your own accent
you may get a hint of the authors accent but you do not hear it
exactly because you are using your own sound-letter map which sounds
vary slightly from the authors. It's why most Americans will be able
to read the top example in their own accent wherever they are from and
change almost no letters. It's really quite an ingenious system:
phonetic, fast and relatively consistent spelling.

-Tony
